title: Myer judgment will have 'chilling effect' on boards
text:
But he ruled that shareholders had not suffered any loss because of "the hard-edged scepticism" of analysts who doubted Myer's claims it would beat the $98.5 million profit it posted in the 2014 financial year. Myer issued a profit downgrade in March 2015 and eventually reported a profit of $77.5 million.

Mr Armour said transparency had become critical as companies like WiseTech and iSignthis came under attack over claims of inflated valuations, but the case might have a chilling effect.

"Justice Beach has accepted investors don't have to individually prove they relied on information, but can rely on general movements in the market," Mr Armour said.

The director lobby group said there should be a review of continuous disclosure laws – as proposed by the Australian Law Reform Commission in January –and that they may need to be relaxed following a surge in claims and sky-rocketing directors and officers' liability insurance.

'Australian directors are more exposed'

The AICD's latest director index sentiment released on Friday shows that 70 per cent of directors already agree or strongly agree that boards are being too risk-averse.

"The consequence is boards who are already being very cautious and risk-averse is they will want to say even less and be more conservative about forward-looking statements," Mr Armour said.

"Australian directors are more exposed than any other developed economy because they have fewer protections on forward-looking statements."

Advertisement

The AICD said law firm Herbert Smith Freehills had recently advised that Australia was out of step with similar regimes in the US and UK.

Mr Armour said they found "any forward-looking representation to the market is taken to be misleading if the person making the representation does not have reasonable grounds for making the statement".

At the same time, that presumption in the law is combined with a lack of a "safe harbour" defence for forward-looking statements that is available in the US and Canada.

Freehills partner Jason Betts said there was “good and bad news” for corporate Australia.

“The bad news is there was uncertainty as to whether our courts would actually find companies in breach of the continuous disclosure obligations and would they interpret those obligations strictly – and the courts have for the first time ever said, ‘we will’.

“I say strictly because Myer was not seeking to guide. The board had not authorised the statement to be given to the market, it wasn’t a formal ASX announcement.

“But what Justice Beach said is, ‘I'm not really interested in, in anything other than what a reasonable person would expect you to do. And I don't care that analysts knew better. If your CEO said, ‘we're going to grow profit in 2015’ and that wasn't true, you had to correct it, even if the market knew better."

Advertisement

The good news, Mr Betts said, was that “when it comes to loss, the courts will take a pragmatic and commercial approach, and I will ask the fundamental question: did your breach actually caused loss to shareholders?”

Mr Walker, the CEO of litigation funder Investor Claim Partner and president of the chairman of the Association of Litigation Funders, said “there was not enough loss” in the Myer claim to make it viable. “We had a look at the figures and they didn’t stack up.”

He said the decision meant there was no more ambiguity around corporate continuous disclosure laws or market-based causation.

“We can't go to mediations any more and spend a lot of time and effort and money on arguing both sides of the fence.”

Andrew Watson, the head of Maurice Blackburn’s class actions practice, said Justice Beach had shown that plaintiff claims had been proceeding on the right basis.

“You can give a forecast which is right at the time it's given because it is based on reasonable grounds. But at a subsequent point in time, you've got to inform the market that you no longer going to make it.

“That's been clear for a very long time but we've got a judicial stamp on what most corporations would have regarded as good practice and common sense.”
description: Boards will “inevitably” become more cautious in issuing profit forecasts after the landmark judgment that found Myer misled the market in late 2014, according to the peak body for company directors.
